questions.text: For which of the following is a vaccine given as a nasal spray?
questions.solution:
• Live attenuated vaccine for influenza is administered as a single dose intranasal spray.
  • It can be given to all between 2 and 49 years.
  • It is not given to people with an immuno-compromised state.
  • Rotavirus vaccine is given orally.
  • Vaccines for measles and Japanese encephalitis are given subcutaneously.

questions.text: An interview which is used to note the gradual influence of some social or psychological process is_____
questions.solution:
A repetitive interview is used to note the gradual influence of some social or psychological process. A record is maintained to understand the changes.

A direct or structured interview consists of predetermined questions and sequence.

A non-directive or unstructured interview doesn’t have any sequence of questions set beforehand. The interviewer listens and allows the speaker to narrate his/her own experiences or opinions.

A focused interview is usually used to study effects of mass communications like radio broadcasts or film. In this, the interviewer/researcher focuses on a particular aspect on the problem and draws responses from people.

questions.text: All of the following can be used for the secondary prevention of mental illness in patients except:
questions.solution:
Improving the social environment is a method of primary prevention of mental illness, not secondary prevention. 

The levels of prevention of mental illness and measures are given below:

  • Primary prevention - improving the social environment and the promotion of mental health awareness
  • Secondary prevention - early diagnosis and family-based health services like casework and family counseling
  • Tertiary prevention - measures to reduce the duration of mental illness as well family and community stresses to prevent further breakdown and disruption

questions.text: Most sensitive tool for evaluating iron status of the body:
questions.solution:
• Serum ferritin measurement is the most sensitive tool for evaluating iron status especially in areas with low prevalence of anemia.
  • Other measures include hemoglobin concentration, serum iron concentration and serum transferring saturation.

questions.text: Ujjawala Scheme includes all the following except:
questions.solution:
• Ujjawala Scheme doesn’t include remuneration.
  • Ujjawala Scheme was begun to comprehensively fight child trafficking.
  • It was launched by the Ministry of Women and Child Development in 2007.
  • It involves:
    • Formation of vigilance groups and awareness groups.
    • Rescue of children being exploited.
    • Rehabilitation of children with provision of shelter, amenities, medical and legal care.
    • Re-integration of these children into the society.
    • Repatriation of the cross-border children to their country of origin.

questions.text: The prevalence of the disease 'X' in a population is 30%. The diagnostic test for this disease has a specificity of 0.80 and a sensitivity of 0.90. What is the negative predictive value of the test?
questions.solution:
The negative predictive value of the above test is 95%.

For convenience, let us assume that the total population in this scenario is 100.

The prevalence of the disease is 30%. So the total number of people with the disease is 30(TP+FN) and disease-free(FP+TN) is 70.

Since sensitivity is 0.90, i.e. TP/(TP + FN) = 90%.

The total true positives (TP) = 90/100 x (TP+FN) = 90/100 x 30 = 27

False-negative(FN) = 30-27 = 3

Since specificity is 0.80, i.e. TN/(FP+TN) = 80%.

Total true negatives (TN) =(FP+TN) x 80/100 = 70 x 80/100 = 56

False-positive(FP) = 70-56 = 14

The given data is represented below:

 

Disease +

Disease -

Total

Test +

27 (TP)

14 (FP)

41

Test -

3 (FN)

56 (TN)

59

Total

30(TP+FN)

70(FP+TN) 

100

Negative predictive value (NPV) = TN/(FN + TN) x 100 = 56/59 = 0.949 = 95%.

An alternate formula(Bayes theorem) that can be used is NPV = (1-P) x Sp /[P x (1-Sn)] +[(1-P) x Sp]

Sn- Sensitivity, P- Prevalence, Sp- Specificity

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: All of the following are required during a cholera outbreak except:
questions.solution:
• Mass chemoprophylaxis is not advised during a cholera outbreak.
  • Chemoprophylaxis can be given to household contacts of a cholera case.
  • Other important measures are supply of safe water, rehydration therapy and health education.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a method to reduce confounding?
questions.solution:
Deletion is not a method to reduce confounding.

Methods to reduce confounding:

  • At the time of designing the study:
    • Randomization
    • Matching
    • Restriction
  • At the time of analysis:
    • Stratification
    • Statistical modelling like regression analysis, multivariate analysis and the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel method.

questions.text: Cereals are pulses are considered as supplementary foods as:

choices.text: Cereals are deficient in lysine and pulses are deficient in methionine
Cereals are deficient in methionine and pulses are deficient in lysine
Both cereals and pulses contain threonine

questions.solution:
• Cereal proteins are deficient in lysine and threonine.
  • Pulse proteins are deficient in methionine.
  • These are known as limiting amino acids as they are most deficient in the food items.
  • Thus, a combination of two or more food items would form a proper vegetarian diet in absence of meat proteins.

questions.text: The STEPS by WHO is aimed at:

choices.text: Surveillance of risk factors for non-communicable diseases
Surveillance of risk factors for communicable diseases
Surveillance of mortality due to nosocomial infections
Surveillance of morbidity in the visually impaired

questions.solution:
WHO STEPwise approach to Surveillance (STEPS) is used for surveillance of adult risk factors for non-communicable diseases and for stroke surveillance.

WHO STEPS approach is a survey methodology developed to assess risk factors of non-communicable diseases (NCD). It helps the countries to establish an NCD surveillance system. The steps include the following:

  • Questionnaires contain questions about behavioral risk factors like tobacco use, alcohol use, diet, and physical activity. 
  • Physical measurements contain blood pressure, height, weight, and waist size
  • Biochemical measurements contain blood glucose, blood lipids, urinary sodium, and creatinine.  

Surveillance is defined as systematic and continuous data analysis and taking appropriate preventive actions according to the results obtained. Identification of cases that are missed and not notified is known as sentinel surveillance. It is used in communicable diseases such as HIV, malaria, etc. The study population for HIV sentinel surveillance are sex workers, IV drug abusers, transgender people, migrant workers, truck drivers, etc.

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding a Category A bioterrorism agents except:

choices.text: Capacity to cause panic and chaos

questions.solution:
• Category A bioterrorism agents are easy to disseminate.
  • Anthrax comes under Category A.

Related Pearl: Bioterrorism Agents

Description Characteristics Examples
Category A

High priority agents

Easily disseminated

High mortality rate

Capacity to get disseminated

Social disruption

Requires specialised public health resources

 

Bacillus anthracis

Clostridium botulinum

Yersinia pestis

Variola major

Ebola and other hemorrhagic fevers

Lassa fever and other arenaviruses

 
Category B

Moderately well disseminated

Moderate morbidity and low mortality

Coxiella burnetti

Salmonella typhi

Chlamydia psittaci

questions.text: Blood pressure is measured in an individual 5 times a day under the same conditions by a new screening test. All 5 readings obtained are the almost same. What is the attribute of a new screening test being described?
questions.solution:
The attribute of a new screening test to yield the same reading when repeated under the same conditions is called reliability.

Reliability is also called precision or reproducibility.

Related Pearl: Repeatability of a Screening Test

Repeatability is an attribute of an ideal screening test. It is also called reliability, precision, or reproducibility. It implies that the test must give consistent results when repeated on the same individual or material, under the same conditions.

It depends upon three factors:

A. Observer variation

  • All observations are subjected to variations.
  • Intra-observer variations or within-observer variations are when a single observer takes two measurements in the same subject, at the same time and obtained two different results.
  • Inter-observer variations or between-observer variations are when two different observers obtain different results on the same subject or material.
  • They are minimized by standardization of procedures, intensive training of observers, and making use of more observers.

B. Biological variation

  • It is also called subject variation.
  • They are due to changes in the parameters observed, variations in the perceptions of symptoms by patients, and regression to the mean where there is a tendency of values to be at either extreme of the distribution.

C. Errors relating to technical methods is due to the following:

  • Defective instruments
  • Erroneous calibration
  • Faulty reagents
  • Incorrect methods

questions.text: Following table lists the number of deaths due to a variety of reasons in a city during a particular year.  Which of the following statistical representation is appropriate for this data?
questions.solution:
In pie charts, segmented areas of a circle are used to represent statistical data.

Choosing the right graphic form:

Variable Summary Appropraite graphical display
Nominal Propotions

Bar chart

Pie chart 
Ordinal Propotions

Bar chart

Line chart
Numerical Mean standard deviations

Histogram

Frequency

polygon
  Medians and Quartiles

Steam and leaves dsplay

Box plot 
  Mode and range

Histogram

Line chart

questions.text: Maximum recommended number of students in a school class room is:
questions.solution:
• Location: Away from noisy surroundings; kept fenced.
  • Site: 5 acres for primary schools; 10 acres for higher elementary schools.
  • Structure: Exterior walls 10 inch thick and heat resistant.
  • Class room: 1 class room per 40 students maximum and per capita space must be >10 sq. feet.
  • Furniture: Single desks of ‘minus’ type.
  • Doors and windows area must be > 25% of floor area.
  • Color of walls inside should be white.
  • Lighting: Natural light from left side.
  • Water supply: Safe and potable and continuous supply through taps.
  • Lavatory: 1 urinal per 60 students and 1 latrine per 100 students.

questions.text: Under the National Urban Health Mission (NUHM), in metropolitan cities, an Urban Community Health Centre (U-CHC) would have how many beds?
questions.solution:
• In metropolitan cities, a U-CHC would have 100 beds and cater to a population of 5 lakhs.
  • In other places, a U-CHC would cater to a population of 2.5 lakhs with 30 to 50 beds.

Each U-CHC would act as a referral unit for 4-5 Urban Primary Health Centres (U-PHC).

questions.text: International Committee of the Red Cross is based in:
questions.solution:
• The International Committee of the Red Cross is based out of Geneva, Switzerland.
  • The Red Cross is devoted to the service of mankind in peace and war.
  • It was founded by Henry Dunant from Switzerland.
  • It first started with humanitarian service to victims of war and then it branched out to natural disasters. Now it works with a variety of health related issues.

questions.text: Which is not an advantage of mass media communication?

choices.text: Increased influence only in below average educated population
Gives greater support for concentrated programmes

questions.solution:
Mass media includes TV, newspaper, radio, etc.

Advantages:

  • It reaches people even in the most remote areas.
  • It gets the public’s attention.
  • It has increased influence across all educational levels, especially in above average educational level.
  • It gives greater support for concentrated programmes.

Disadvantages:

  • One way communication
  • Impersonal method and no face to face contact

questions.text: Intention-to-treat analysis is done in Randomized Control Trials when there is:
questions.solution:
• Intention-to-treat (ITT) analysis includes the dropouts of the trial.
  • It ignores non-compliance, protocol change, withdrawal, cross-over and anything that happens after randomization during analysis.

questions.text: A village has a total population of 100,000 with an under-16 population at 3%. The prevalence of goitre in the under-16 population is (0.3/100). What is the total number of under-16 population affected by goitre?
questions.solution:
The total number of persons in the under-16 with goitre is 9.

Number of total under-16 population = 3% of 100,000 = 3000.

Thus, total number of goitre patients who are under-16 with the prevalence at the given value = 3000*0.3/100= 9

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

  • Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:

It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

  • In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text: Sand fly doesn’t transmit:
questions.solution:
Sandflies transmit kala azar, Oroya fever, sandfly fever and oriental sores.

Trench fever is transmitted by lice.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about screw-feed technology in biomedical waste management?
questions.solution: Pathological wastes, cytotoxic wastes, and radioactive wastes are not processed using screw-feed technology.

questions.text: Who makes the final selection of the village health guides?
questions.solution:
• 2 to 3 candidates, based on the guidelines, would be suggested by the community.
  • The medical officer in charge would then choose one of them to be the VHG in consultation with the block development officer and field staff.

questions.text: All are functions of a primary health care centre in India except:

choices.text: Collection and record of vital events

questions.solution:
A primary health centre acts as a referral unit for 6 sub-centres.

Related Pearl: Primary Health Centres-PHC

  • HWC-PHCs: Population of 30000 in plains, 20000 in hilly/tribal areas
  • Urban HWC-PHCs: Population of 50000
  • Specialist UPHC/Polyclinic (urban): Population of 2.5- 3 lakh

PHC’s and UPHC’s can be further extended to 24X7 PHC’s/UPHC’s

Bed distribution: 

HWC-PHC HWC-UPHC 24X7 HWC-PHC/UPHC
Essential: 2 beds Essential: 2 daycare beds Essential: 6 beds
Desirable: +4 beds Desirable: +4 daycare beds Desirable: +4 beds

Note: The desirable will be over and above the essential beds.

The twelve packages envisaged under Comprehensive Primary Healthcare services (CPHC): 

  1. Care in Pregnancy and Childbirth 
  2. Neonatal and Infant Health Care Services
  3. Childhood and Adolescent Health Care Services
  4. Family Planning, Contraceptive Services, and other Reproductive Health Care Services
  5. Management of Communicable Diseases: National Health Programmes
  6. General Out-patient Care for Acute Simple Illnesses and Minor Ailments
  7. Screening, Prevention, Control and Management of Non-communicable Diseases
  8. Care for Common Ophthalmic and ENT Problems
  9. Basic Oral Health Care
  10. Elderly and Palliative Health Care Services
  11. Emergency Medical Services including Burns and Trauma
  12. Screening and Basic Management of Mental Health Ailments.

IPHS 2022 normal for manpower at PHC:

Essential manpower for:

1) PHC: 12   2) UPHC: 16   3) Polyclinic: 22   4) 24x7 PHC: 23   5) 24X7 UPHC: 27

questions.text: Which would be the best method to teach a slum population about ORS and its usage?
questions.solution:
• Demonstration is a carefully prepared presentation on how to perform a certain task or skill or procedure.
  • It shows the step by step process of a task.
  • Demonstration arouses interest, incites ‘learning by doing’ and ‘seeing is believing’ philosophies.

questions.text: Soil is a reservoir for all the following except:
questions.solution:
• Main reservoir of the coccobacilli of the genus Brucella that cause brucellosis are animals like sheep, cattle, horses, goats, whales and dogs.
  • The natural reservoir for tetanus causing Clostridium tetani is soil and dust. They also are present in intestines of many herbivorous animals.
  • Bacillus anthracis is a soil commensal and is also found on the hides and dried skins of infected aminals.
  • Coccidiomycosis is also called Valley fever and the causative fungi belong to the Coccidiodes species. The main reservoir of this organism is soil.
  • A reservoir is the environment (eg. Soil, humans, animals, water) where the infectious agent lives and multiples and from where it can be transmitted to a susceptible host.

questions.text: Identify the type of epidemic from the following epidemic curve:
questions.solution:
• In the epidemic curve for a point source epidemic, there is a sharp rise and fall of the curve with no secondary waves.
  • It tends to be explosive as all the cases are clustered in a narrow period of time and they occur within one incubation period of the disease.

Related Pearl: Epidemics and its Types

An epidemic is an occurrence in a community or region of cases of an illness that is clearly in excess of normal expectancy. Its types include:

Common source epidemics

  • Single exposure or 'point source' epidemics
  • Multiple or continuous exposure epidemics

Propagated or progressive epidemics

  • Person to person
  • Arthropod vector
  • Animal reservoir

Slow or modern epidemics

  • Non-communicable diseases

questions.text: To calculate the positive predictive value of a new screening test for breast carcinoma, what will you use for the denominator?
questions.solution:
The denominator for the calculation of the positive predictive value of a screening test is true positives + false positives.

Positive predictive value (PPV) of a test is TP/(TP + FP) x 100.

It indicates the probability that a person with a positive test actually has the disease. It is directly proportional to the prevalence of a disease.

Predictive value is affected by sensitivity, specificity, and prevalence. However, it is affected the most by prevalence.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: Pearl Index is defined as:

choices.text: Accidental pregnancies per 1000 women-years of exposure
Accidental pregnancies per 100 women-years of exposure
Accidental pregnancies per 10 women-years of exposure
Total accidental pregnancies caused in one year by number of contraceptives used

questions.solution:
• Pearl Index is accidental pregnancies per 100 women-years of exposure (HWY).
  • It is a measure of contraceptive failure.

questions.text: How would you define socialized medicine?

choices.text: Subsidized medical care at government's expense
Free medical care provided and regulated by government alone
Free medical care at government expense, regulated by professional groups
Integration of social medicine with health care

questions.solution:
Socialized medicine is the provision of medical service at the government's expense but is operated and regulated by professional groups, and not the government. Russia was the first country to completely socialize medicine.

Free medical care by a government alone is called state medicine.

questions.text: What is the risk ratio when the incidence of the disease in exposed is 30 and that in non-exposed is 5?
questions.solution:
The risk ratio or relative risk here is 6 per 1000.

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where, 
  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text: Which is not an element of evaluation?
questions.solution:
Components of evaluation are:

Relevance, adequacy, accessibility, acceptability, effectiveness, efficiency and effect or impact.

questions.text: The Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) is related to:

choices.text: Sanitation and safe drinking water supply

questions.solution:
• The Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RSBK) has provisions for Child Health Screening and Early Intervention Services.
  • It is done through early detection and management in terms of defects at birth, diseases in children, deficiency conditions and developmental delays including disabilities – called the 4 Ds.

questions.text: Who was the architect of the Public Health Act of 1848?
questions.solution:
Edwin Chadwick was the architect of the Public Health Act of 1848.

He was an English lawyer during the 1832 cholera epidemic. He compiled a report on the Sanitary Condition of the Labouring Population in Great Britain that eventually led to the passing of this act. It is considered a landmark act in the history of public health.

questions.text: What is the maximum timeline of maternal death that is included in the calculation of maternal mortality ratio?
questions.solution:
Maternal mortality ratio (MMR) is the death of a woman while pregnant within or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, from any cause related to the pregnancy or its management but not by accidental causes.

MMR is given by (Total deaths during pregnancy or 42 days after termination due to pregnancy related causes, in an area in a year x 100,000)/ (Total live births in that area in that year).

questions.text: Which of the following is an indicator for operational efficiency for National Vector-Borne Diseases Control Programme?
questions.solution:
• Annual blood examination rate (ABER) is an index of operational efficiency. It is given by (Number of slides examined x 100)/Total population.
  • Annual parasite incidence (API) is used to classify areas as high risk or low risk. It is given by (Confirmed cases during one year x 100)/ Population under surveillance. If API is greater than or equal to 2 per 1000 population, then that area is high risk.
  • Other indicators used are slide positivity rate and annual falciparum rate.

questions.text: The first bacterium discovered as a cause of the disease was:
questions.solution:
The first bacterium discovered as a cause of the disease is leprosy bacillus.

In 1873, Armauer Hansen demonstrated Mycobacterium leprae (rod-like bodies) from a leprosy nodule. This is the first time that chronic infectious disease in humans was shown to be related to a bacillus.

In 1876, Robert Koch validated the germ theory of disease after discovering the anthrax bacillus as the cause of anthrax.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of multiphasic screening?

choices.text: Chest X-ray for TB in large populations
Pap smear in women above 40 years
Random blood sugar during antenatal visits

questions.solution:
Annual health checkups are an example of multiphasic screening.

Types of screening:

  1. Multiphasic screening is the application of two or more screening tests in combination with a large number of people at one time. Example- Annual health checkups.
  2. High-risk or selective screening is done on high-risk groups. Example- MRI screening of breast done annually in 25-year old women with BRCA 1, BRCA 2 mutations in a first-degree relative.
  3. Mass screening is a screening of a whole or large population like using a chest X-ray for TB screening in large populations. It is done for diseases with high prevalence.

questions.text: In which country was the last case of naturally occurring smallpox in the world recorded?
questions.solution:
The last case of naturally occurring smallpox was in Somalia in 1977.

The last case of smallpox occurred in 1978 when a medical photographer was accidentally exposed to the smallpox virus in a research laboratory in Birmingham.

India was declared smallpox-free on 24th May 1975. WHO declared smallpox as eradicated globally on 8th May 1980.

questions.text: Chadah committee did not recommend which of the following?

choices.text: One basic health worker per 10,000 population
Responsibility of PHCs in malaria eradication

questions.solution:
• Key person in Chadah committee was Dr. M. S. Chadah.
  • Concept of multipurpose health worker was given by Kartar Singh Committee.

Related Pearl: Health Planning Committees of India

Year

Name

Concepts and Programmes

1946

Bhore committee
  • Also called Health Survey and Development Committee
  • 1 PHC for 40,000 population
  • 3 million plan
  • 3 months training in PSM for physicians
  • Preventive and curative services at all administrative levels 

1962

Mudaliar committee
  • Also known as Health Survey and Planning Committee
  • District hospitals to have specialists
  • 1 PHC for not more than 40,000 people
  • Constitution of All India Health Service

1963

Chadah committee
  • Outlined responsibility of PHCs in the National Malaria Eradication Programme
  • One basic health worker for 10,000 population 

1965

Mukerji committee
  • Delinked malaria activities from family planning activities.
  • Family planning assistants were for family planning work and basic health workers for other activities.

1966

Mukerji committee
  • Also called committee of Health Secretaries.
  • Detailed the Basic Health Service to be given at block level 

1967

Jungalwalla committee
  • Also called Committee on Integration of Health Services
  • Ban of private practice by government doctors
  • Equal pay for equal work and special pay for specialized work

1973

Kartar Singh committee
  • Also called Committee on Multipurpose Workers under Health and Family Planning
  • Recommended male and female health workers
  • 1 PHC for 50,000 population
  • Each PHC to have 16 sub-centres
  • Each sub-centre to have one male and one female health worker

1975

Shrivastav committee
  • Also called Group on Medical Education and Support Manpower
  • Referral Services Complex
  • Rural Health Infrastructure of Sub centre, PHC and CHC
  • ROME scheme – Reorientation of health education
  • Establishment of Medical and Health Education Commission
  • Village Health Guide scheme
  • Bands of semi–professional and Para-professional Health workers 

1983

Krishnan committee

 
  • Urban Revamping Scheme
  • Integration of PHC       

1986

Bajaj committee
  • Formulation of National Medical and Health Education Policy.
  • Formulation of National Manpower Policy.
  • Health Manpower cells
  • Education commission.

questions.text: The Harpenden calipers are used in public health to_____

choices.text: Measure turgidity of skin in dehydration

questions.solution:
Harpenden calipers are used to measure skin fold thickness.

Skin fold thickness is a measure used in estimating body fat percentage for anthropometry in understanding nutritional status.

questions.text: All of the following are true about Q fever except:

choices.text: Causative agent is Coxiella burnetti and ticks are reservoirs
Ticks are the main vector in transmission to man
Doxycycline is a drug that is used for treatment

questions.solution:
• There is no vector involved in the transmission of the disease Q fever to man.
  • Ticks are reservoirs for the causative bacteria, Coxiella burnetti.
  • It is a zoonotic disease that is transmitted to man by inhalation of contaminated dust by infected animals.
  • Incubation period usually lasts for 2 to 3 weeks.
  • Clinical manifestations can range from fever and chills to pneumonia and hepatitis.
  • There is no skin lesion.
  • Doxycycline is a commonly used antibiotic for this disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about the National Health Policy of 2017?

choices.text: Increase public health expenditure to 5% of GDP by 2025
Access to safe water and sanitation to all by 2020
Achieve elimination of lymphatic filariasis by 2017

questions.solution: The public health expenditure is to be increased to 2.5% of the GDP by 2025.

questions.text: Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) for calcium for non-pregnant women per day is:
questions.solution:
RDA for calcium for non-pregnant women is 600 mg/day.

Recommended intake of calcium (mg/d):

Group Calcium
Adult men 600
Adult women 600
Pregnancy 1200
Lactation 1200
Post menopausal women 800
Infants 500
Children 1-3 years 600
Children 4-6 years 600
Children 7-9 years 600
Children 10-12 year 800 (Both boys and girls)
Children 13-15 years 800 (Both boys and girls)
Children 16-18 years 800 (Both boys and girls)

To achieve thi level of intake, a minimum of 200 ml of milk/d would be essential on cereale- legume diet

questions.text: If the systolic BP in a population has a mean of 130 mmHg and a median of 140 mmHg, the distribution is said to be:

choices.text: Either negatively or positively skewed depending upon the standard deviation

questions.solution:
This is a negatively skewed distribution.

In any skewed distribution (i.e., positive or negative), the median will always fall in between the mean and the mode.

For a positively skewed distribution, the mean will always be the highest estimate of central tendency, and the mode will always be the lowest estimate of central tendency (assuming that the distribution has only one mode).

For negatively skewed distributions, the mean will always be the lowest estimate of central tendency, and the mode will be the highest estimate of central tendency.

In this scenario, the median is greater than the mean. As the median lies at a point in between the mean and the mode, this indicates a negatively skewed distribution.

questions.text: Ingestion of which of the following can lead to ergotism?
questions.solution:
• Food items like bajra, rye, sorghum and wheat have a tendency to house the ergot fungus called Claviceps purpurea.
  • They can be removed from grains by floating them in 20% salt water.
  • They can be also removed by hand-picking and air floatation.
  • Safe limit for ergot alkaloids in grains is 0.05 mg per 100 grams.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the Rashtriya Swasthya Bima Yojana?

choices.text: It is a wide-reaching employment scheme
Initially aimed at the population below poverty line
Information technology is used on a large scale

questions.solution:
Rashtriya Swasthya Bima Yojana (RSBY) is a health insurance scheme aimed at the population below poverty line, initially but now it now covers other unrecognized working sectors.

Some salient features of the RSBY are:

  • Beneficiaries are entitled to hospitalization worth 30,000 rupees with other costs like transportation also covered to a maximum of 1000 rupees per year.
  • This scheme is information technology intensive.
  • Cashless transactions at hospitals through a smart card.
  • Enrollment with RSBY to be linked with opening of bank account and issuance of Aadhaar card.
  • Scheme currently covers 3 crore workers. It will be expanded to include construction sector also.
  • Single central smart card to be issued to include other welfare schemes like Aam Aadmi Bima Yojana and National Old Age Pension Scheme.

questions.text: An endemic disease in which the children in an area show high level of pathogenic responses while the majority of the adults remain to be asymptomatic carriers is referred to as_______
questions.solution:
A holoendemic disease is a disease in which the children in an area show higher prevalence and pathogenic responses to the disease compared to the adults, who tend to either be asymptomatic carriers or show reduced damage by the disease, eg. Malaria.

A hyperendemic disease is one which is constantly present at high incidence and prevalence among all groups in a population.

An endemic disease refers to a disease that is present constantly in a population or in a given area without importation from outside.

questions.text: Cooling power of air is measured by_______
questions.solution:
Kata thermometer is an alcohol thermometer that measures the cooling power of air.

Hygrometer and psychrometers are useful in measurement of humidity.

Anemometers are used for measuring air speed.

questions.text: Hidden hunger refers to:

choices.text: Food shortage cause of by famines

questions.solution:
• Hidden hunger refers to micronutrient deficiency and it occurs when there is deficiency in intake or absorption of micronutrients like vitamins, iron, zinc, etc.
  • The health and development of a community are affected by less obvious or invisible effects of these deficiencies. Thus they are referred to as hidden hunger.
  • Consequences of hidden hunger are seen in all ages.

questions.text: Income generated only within the country is represented by:
questions.solution: Gross Domestic Product (GDP) is the gross income generated in the country and doesn’t include the income received from abroad.
